channel.title: NYT > Business > Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: G.O.P. Again Cedes Power on Tariffs to Avoid Crossing Trump
item.description: House Republicans extended a maneuver they engineered earlier in the year that effectively strips Congress of the power to disapprove of President Trump’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison

item.title: U.S. and China Reach ‘Framework’ for a TikTok Sale
item.description: Top economic officials met in Madrid for a second day, with deadlines looming on tariffs and a ban on TikTok in the United States if it is not sold by its Chinese owner, ByteDance.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and José Bautista

item.title: U.S. and China Resume Talks on Tariffs and TikTok
item.description: Economic officials meeting in Madrid are seeking to head off a November tariff deadline.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Did Britain Win the Trade War? Why It’s Tough to Declare a Victor.
item.description: Popular products from Britain and the European Union show how uneven and unpredictable U.S. tariffs have become, even when part of trade deals.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson, Jeanna Smialek, Ani Matevosian and Lucia Calfapietra

item.title: Hyundai ICE Raid Detained Workers With Short-Term Business Visas
item.description: Last week’s immigration operation at a battery plant highlighted a tactic that companies use to bring in foreign workers to establish new operations.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Hamed Aleaziz

item.title: How Howard Lutnick Is Using Government Power to Pressure Private Companies
item.description: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick has been putting the squeeze on companies and trading partners in an unusual effort to raise revenue and expand the president’s role over the economy.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump’s Economic Agenda Hinges on the Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.description: For the president, the power to issue limitless tariffs is at the heart of his second-term vision, from trade to foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Ana Swanson

item.title: Mounting Deportations Meet Slow Hiring in a ‘Curious Kind of Balance’
item.description: An influx of immigrants helped ease worker shortages, and now their expulsion is helping to mask the country’s weakening demand for labor.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Scott Mcintyre For The New York Times

item.title: US Poverty Rate Was Stable in 2024, as Household Income Rose Slightly
item.description: As pandemic subsidies disappeared, wages kept workers just ahead of inflation, although gaps have widened for some groups.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: A Second Weak Jobs Report Challenges Trump’s Claim the Economy Is Booming
item.description: After a bad employment report in August, President Trump fired the official in charge of the numbers. This month’s data was just as disappointing.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Ben Casselman

item.title: U.S. Imports Rose in July Following Months of Trade Turmoil
item.description: Trade rebounded slightly after President Trump’s sweeping global tariffs discouraged foreign countries from doing business with the United States, data released Thursday showed.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Signals Imminent Supreme Court Appeal to Protect Tariffs
item.description: The president said he would seek expedited review of a federal appeals court’s ruling that found many of his administration’s tariffs to be illegal.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Ana Swanson

item.title: Nothing Could Topple the ‘Queen of Heels.’ Then Trump Came Along.
item.description: The president’s steep tariffs and erratic moves have turned manufacturing abroad into a minefield, even for entrepreneurs who set up in countries viewed as safe alternatives to China.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Family Profits Even With Tepid Launch of Crypto Tokens
item.description: World Liberty Financial’s cryptocurrency token fell short of investors’ hopes. But a previous deal paved the way for a payment to the Trump family of potentially hundreds of millions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton

item.title: How Trump Could Gain Control of the Fed
item.description: President Trump’s attempt to fire Lisa Cook has laid bare the erosion of the Federal Reserve’s independence, which could lead to economic consequences for Americans, The New York Times’s chief economics correspondent explains.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman, Melanie Bencosme, June Kim, Gabriel Blanco and Jon Hazell

item.title: Trump’s Sweeping Tariffs Invalidated by Appeals Court
item.description: The decision is a big blow to President Trump’s trade policies, but the judges left the duties in place for now to allow time for a likely appeal to the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Ana Swanson

item.title: The A.I. Spending Frenzy Is Propping Up the Real Economy, Too
item.description: The trillions of dollars that tech companies are pouring into new data centers are starting to show up in economic growth. For now, at least.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Lisa Cook Defies Trump Bid to Fire Her as Fed Governor
item.description: Ms. Cook said that she would not resign from the Board of Governors, hours after President Trump announced he was firing her.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Europe Is Spending Big on Defense. Will That Help Its Ailing Economy?
item.description: Leaders in Britain and the European Union are promoting the promise of economic benefits from increased military spending, but there is a trade-off.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: Trump Starts Investigation That Could Lead to Tariffs on Wind Turbines
item.description: The tariffs would hamper a clean energy industry that the president has often railed against.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
